Review Enhancing selectivity in acidic CO2 electrolysis: Cation effects and catalyst innovation Zichao Huang Tinghui Yang Yingbing Zhang Chaoqun Guan Wenke Gui Min Kuang * Jianping Yang * State Key Laboratory for Modification of Chemical Fibers and Polymer Materials, College of Materials Science and Engineering, Donghua University, Shanghai 201620, China State Key Laboratory for Modification of Chemical Fibers and Polymer Materials College of Materials Science and Engineering Donghua University Shanghai 201620 China State Key Laboratory for Modification of Chemical Fibers and Polymer Materials, College of Materials Science and Engineering, Donghua University, Shanghai 201620, China * Corresponding author. The electrochemical reduction of CO2 (eCO2R) under ambient conditions is crucial for reducing carbon emissions and achieving carbon neutrality. Despite progress with alkaline and neutral electrolytes, their efficiency is limited by (bi)carbonates formation. Acidic media have emerged as a solution, addressing the (bi)carbonates challenge but introducing the issue of the hydrogen evolution reaction (HER), which reduces CO2 conversion efficiency in acidic environments. This review focuses on enhancing the selectivity of acidic CO2 electrolysis. It commences with an overview of the latest advancements in acidic CO2 electrolysis, focusing on product selectivity and electrocatalytic activity enhancements. It then delves into the critical factors shaping selectivity in acidic CO2 electrolysis, with a special emphasis on the influence of cations and catalyst design. Finally, the research challenges and personal perspectives of acidic CO2 electrolysis are suggested. Graphical Abstract Rational design of catalysts can improve the selectivity of eCO2R in acidic conditions, thereby facilitating the efficient conversion of eCO2R and its application in industrial processes. Keywords Acidic CO2 electrolysis High selectivity Cation effects Catalyst design Competitive HER 1 Introduction Carbon dioxide (CO2), as a sustainable and secure source of carbon and oxygen, holds potential as an energy precursor. The chemical conversion of CO2 into valuable fuels and chemicals offers a dual benefit: it mitigates rising CO2 levels and reduces reliance on fossil fuels, which is crucial for easing the energy-environmental pressures [1–3]. Electrochemical CO2 reduction (eCO2R) technology, operating at room temperature with electricity from clean energy sources such as solar, wind, and tidal power, presents an efficient route for industrial fuel and chemical generation [4–6]. It is generally accepted that for eCO2R to be economically viable, the current density must exceed 0.2 A cm−2 and the product's Faraday efficiency (FE) must be greater than 80% [7]. Recent advancements, including the extensive adoption of gas diffusion electrodes (GDE) and flow-cell technology, have significantly propelled the progress of eCO2R technology. Neutral and alkaline aqueous media are widely used as electrolytes because increasing the pH can reduce the energy required for CO2 activation and inhibit the competition of hydrogen evolution. This is conducive to CO2 conversion, making achieving high FE and low overpotential easier [8]. In recent years, the performance of eCO2R in neutral and alkaline media has greatly improved, especially in terms of the selectivity and current density of C1 products such as CO and formate, which have reached industrial benchmarks [9–11]. However, these electrolytes pose challenges; acidic CO2 molecules can react with hydroxide ions (OH−) to form (bi)carbonates, which clog GDE pores, leading to electrode leakage and reduced durability [12,13]. At the same time, (bi)carbonates may traverse the anion exchange membrane (AEM), undergoing protonation to regenerate CO2 at the anode, leading to diminished single-pass carbon efficiency (SPCE) [14]. Recent techno-economic analyses highlight that recuperating CO2 lost to the electrolyte and anode tail gas needs energy, potentially nullifying eCO2R's energy efficiency and constraining its practical applications [15,16]. In contrast, acidic eCO2R mitigates the adverse effects associated with (bi)carbonates formation [17,18]. At the cathode, it can protonate locally formed carbonate back into CO2, enhancing energy utilization efficiency and potentially achieving a 100% SPCE, thereby eliminating the need for costly product separation and presenting a solution with significant industrial promise [19]. However, the increased acidity narrows the voltage window for the HER, complicating the equilibrium between carbon efficiency and eCO2R performance under acidic conditions due to rapid HER rates and stringent reaction environments [20–23]. A promising remedial approach involves utilizing high concentrations of alkali metal cations to improve eCO2R selectivity [24–26]. In acidic eCO2R systems, electrolytes typically comprise inorganic acids and metal salts [27,28]. Distinct from alkaline and neutral eCO2R (Table 1 ), which employ anion exchange membranes (AEM) to segregate cathode and anode, acidic systems generally utilize cation exchange membranes (CEM), with perfluorosulfonic acid-based membranes like Nafion, Selemion, Hyflon, and Aquaivion being prevalent [29,30]. These ensure H+ ions act as charge carriers, inhibiting CO2 crossover at the anode [31]. Anode electrolytes frequently contain low-concentration sulfuric acid or alkali metal sulfate solutions [32]. Nonetheless, this necessitates acid-tolerant oxygen evolution reaction (OER) catalysts incorporating costly precious metals like Ir, Ru, and Pt, which are obstacles to scaling up electrolyzers [33]. Employing a bipolar membrane (BPM), inspired by amphoteric water electrolysis, circumvents these issues by enabling the simultaneous use of alkaline and acidic solutions on respective sides and the application of cost-effective OER catalysts, such as nickel foam [34]. However, BPM's higher resistance leads to increased reaction voltage, substantially limiting operational current density [29,35]. Research in acidic medium eCO2R is still at an early stage. The catalysts reported to date need further improvements in selectivity and activity, particularly for the generation of multi-carbon (C2+) products. Developing catalysts suitable for industrial applications demands a deeper insight into the reaction mechanisms involved. This emergent and complex area of research benefits from a timely synthesis of existing literature to stimulate future investigations and foster eCO2R progress. In this review, we discuss recent key progress in acidic CO2 electrolysis within the cationic effect and catalyst design to highlight the necessity of improving the selectivity of acidic CO2 electrolysis. We begin with a brief review of the development of acidic CO2 electrolysis and discuss the challenges in this field. Subsequently, the role of alkali metal cations in acidic media was further elucidated. Alkali metal cations maximize CO2 enrichment to improve eCO2R kinetics by stabilizing key intermediates and regulating H+ diffusion in solution. On this basis, we present examples that directly or indirectly utilize cationic effects through catalyst design, including catalyst morphology design, wettability regulation, functional material modification, and the construction of the tandem structure. In addition, eCO2R in metal-free cationic acidic media is further investigated. Finally, we look forward to the future development direction, hope can inspire and motivate more acidic CO2 electrolysis research, accelerate the industrialization process of eCO2R, and achieve the goal of carbon neutrality. 2 Advancements and challenges in acidic CO2 electrolysis Alkali metal sulfates, halides, and phosphates are the most widely used metal salts. The sulfate anion has the highest electrical conductivity. Halide anions have high solubility. Phosphoric acid has a good buffering capacity. The pursuit of acidic eCO2R has gained momentum as a response to the limitations posed by increased alkalinity. As illustrated in the H2O-CO2 equilibrium diagram (Fig. 1(a) ), heightened acidity circumvents the protonation of CO2 in the water [36]. Therefore, conducting eCO2R under acidic media below the pK a of carbonic acid is promising to address the “carbonate issue”. The initial exploration into acidic eCO2R was undertaken by Koper's group in 2015, showcasing a cobalt protoporphyrin immobilized on a pyrolytic graphite electrode capable of reducing CO2 in acidic solutions [37]. However, the reaction kinetics are constrained, with the HER predominantly occurring. The kinetics of eCO2R is affected by the pH of the electrolyte. It is generally believed that as the pH of the electrolyte increases, the rate of eCO2R will accelerate. In the process of eCO2R, CO2 molecules are first activated to produce *CO2, and further protonated to produce *CO2H. Then *CO2H will evolve into formic acid or *CO. Depending on the difference in the affinity of the catalyst surface to *CO, *CO will desorption to CO or further reduction to produce multi-electron transfer C1 products and C2+ products. The continued evolution of *CO to C2+ products depends on the affinity of the catalyst surface for *CO and need to overcome a higher energy barrier. In acidic media, fast HERs impede the activation of CO2 molecules, which is the rate-determining step in the conversion of CO2 to formic acid and CO [38]. The initial two electrons transfer is more likely to participate in HER than in eCO2R, which further leads to difficulties in subsequent C–C coupling, this is the rate-determining step in the CO2-C2+ product conversion [39]. How to activate more CO2 molecules while inhibiting HER is a major challenge in achieving high-performance acidic CO2 electrolysis. Looking back at the development of acidic CO2 electrolysis, this problem was solved in 2021. Sargent et al. [20] found that adding base cations to acidic medium can significantly inhibit HER and improve the kinetics of eCO2R, reinvigorating interest in acidic CO2 electrolysis. Table 2 summarizes a series of high-performance acidic eCO2R catalysts developed in recent years, and it can be seen that great breakthroughs have been made in selectivity and activity. However, the reported catalyst stability in acidic media is generally less than 200 h. This is because the catalyst will dissolve or corrode in an acidic environment, resulting in a decrease in catalyst activity. Moreover, the hydrophobic layer of GDE will gradually become hydrophilic with the progress of electrolysis, so that HER will regain the dominant position. To solve the corrosion problem of catalyst in acidic media, Zhong et al. [40] developed an anti-corrosion strategy to improve the stability of common metal CO2R catalysts in strong acids by coating the SiC-NafionTM layer on the catalyst surface. The FE of H2 remained below 10% for the coated catalyst at 100 h electrolysis. After 100 h electrolysis of the catalyst without modified coating, the FE of H2 rose to 50%. The stability in acidic media is still substantially poorer than in neutral and alkaline media, even with the application of anti-corrosion techniques. How to maximize the stability of the catalyst is the challenge facing the further development of acidic CO2 electrolysis. HER competition in acidic media requires controlling catalyst properties and the local microenvironment, which is closely related to the action of alkali metal cations [19]. However, with the progress of the reaction, the accumulation of alkali cations is bound to lead to the crystallization of alkali salts on the catalyst and gas diffusion electrode, thus limiting the life of the cell [41,42]. To improve the sustainability of the electrolytic system, and reduce the dependence on cations, developing catalysts with high intrinsic activity is a new approach for acidic CO2 electrolysis research. Sargent et al. [43] reported that a copper catalyst functionalized with cationic groups was highly efficient in producing multi-carbon products in pure acid solution, with FE of up to 80%. This provides a new idea for efficient industrial application of eCO2R and enables the high-performance overall reaction for practical application toward industrialization. 3 Theory-guided discovery of cations’ actions The efficacy of eCO2R in acidic environments is intricately linked to both the concentration and type of cations present; notably, eCO2R fails to proceed in their absence [22,44,45]. Research conducted by Sargent et al. [20]. examined the eCO2R performance of Cu in mixed electrolytes of H3PO4 and KCl, observing that an increase in K+ concentration led to a diminished selectivity for the HER and enhanced selectivity for eCO2R, as illustrated in Fig. 1(b). Similarly, Monteiro et al. [45] employed cyclic voltammetry on gold electrodes within H2SO4 electrolytes, both with and without metal cation additives, establishing the viability of eCO2R in acidic conditions when specific alkali metal cations are present. As depicted in Fig. 1(c), the inclusion of cations significantly boosts the cathodic reduction current, alongside a notable anodic current surge attributed to the oxidation of produced CO, with the efficacy sequence being Li+ < Na+ < K+ < Cs+ [45]. Both studies underscore the indispensable role of cations in enabling acidic eCO2R, thereby underlining the critical need to elucidate the role of alkali metal cations as a foundational step toward realizing acidic eCO2R. The influence of cations on eCO2R can be encapsulated from two primary perspectives: firstly, they mitigate the activity of the HER, and secondly, they amplify the activity of eCO2R [46]. The electric double layer (EDL), a construct involving the catalyst surface, ions, and crucial intermediates and reactants at the catalyst-electrolyte interface, serves as a central model in discussions of catalyst-electrolyte interactions [47,48]. Fig. 1(d) presents a quintessential schematic of the EDL model, delineating its composition into the Stern layer and a diffusion layer [49,50]. Within this framework, the layer of reversed ions at the charged electrode and electrolyte juncture is identified as the Helmholtz layer, with the inner Helmholtz plane (IHP) representing the electrically central plane constituted by specifically adsorbed species, and the outer Helmholtz plane (OHP) as that composed of solvated ions [51]. The area extending beyond the OHP is referred to as the diffusion layer [52]. The EDL stands as the focal region for cation activity, with simulations of cation behavior within the EDL shedding light on the precise origins and mechanisms underpinning the cation effect. 3.1 Electric field effect induced by cations The interface electric field in EDL plays a key role in stabilizing intermediates and regulating the mass transport of H+. This electric field can alter the energy levels of molecular orbitals in adsorbates, thereby adjusting the adsorption-free energy and activation barriers of intermediates, which in turn influences the activity and selectivity of electrochemical reactions [53]. Especially for eCO2R, key intermediates such as *CO2, *CO, and *OCCO possess large dipole moments, the free energy of these intermediates is highly susceptible to alterations by the cathode's EDL electric field [54]. By introducing an explicit model of the electrochemical interface, Nemerskov et al. [55] studied the effect of hydrated cations and their corresponding interface image charges on the electric field in eCO2R on Ag (111) electrodes. Their findings indicate a notable shift in the free energy of *CO2 under the typical electric field strength generated by double-layer solvated cations (−1.0 V Å−1), rendering the initial step thermodynamically feasible. Furthermore, Gu et al.‘s [56] simulations using the Poisson-Nernst-Planck (PNP) model underscore that cation-induced electric field modulation constitutes the basis of the cation effect. The aggregation of hydrated cations on OHP produces a strong interfacial electric field. The orientation of the electric field in the Stern layer (the area between the electrode surface and the OHP) is consistent with that produced by the cathode, while the orientation in the diffusion layer is opposite to that of the cathode electric field. This interaction of long-range dipole fields stabilizes CO2 − intermediates, thereby boosting eCO2R activity. Concurrently, a diminished electric field strength in the diffusion layer suppresses the migration of H+ and limits the rate of HER. In the solution without metal ions, the weak electric field produced by the aggregation of H+ in OHP is not enough to resist the cathode electric field, so H+ can migrate well under the action of the electric field, resulting in the high activity of HER (Figs. 2(a) and (b) ). In addition, the concentration and type of cations can affect the stability of the electric field on dipoles and polarizable intermediates, resulting in different cation effects. Qin et al. [57] combined electrochemical measurements with the generalized modified Poisson-Nernst-Planck (GMPNP) model to quantitatively assess the effect of cation concentration on the electrochemical reduction of CO2 and H+. They discovered that in an acidic solution, the cation concentration significantly influences H+ mass transfer and the thickness of the diffusion layer. Notably, when the concentration of cations meets or exceeds that of hydrogen ions, there is a reduction in the migration rate of H+. Additionally, an increase in cation concentration correlates with a thicker diffusion layer, consequently restraining the HER reaction rate (Fig. 2(c)). Moreover, the specific type and concentration of M+ cations directly modulate the electric field intensity within the Stern layer, which serves as a pivotal driving force for electron transfer from the cathode to CO2. Fig. 2(d) shows the Stern layer's electric field intensity as induced by various cations in solution, arranged in ascending order of Li+ < Na+ < K+ < Cs+. This arrangement elucidates the profound influence of different cations on the eCO2R reaction rate, showcasing how cation characteristics can significantly dictate the dynamics of eCO2R. Alkali cations prevent proton diffusion, which lowers H+ coverage near the electrode, causing the local OH− concentration to surpass the H+ concentration and subsequently raising the local pH. As shown in Fig. 2(e), in an acidic electrolyte without cations, the local pH value of the cathode surface is significantly lower than the overall pH value of the acidic electrolyte due to the rapid diffusion of H+. In contrast, in the case of cations, the local pH value of the cathode surface is higher than the overall pH value of the electrolyte [58]. Sargent et al. [20] simulated the pH distribution of the cathode at different current densities in 1 mol L−1 H3PO4 + 3 mol L−1 KCl. As shown in Fig. 2(f), the pH near the cathode gradually increases with increasing current density. The increase of local pH influences the kinetics of eCO2R, with methane selectivity rising from 2% to 27%. Cations affect the activity and selectivity of eCO2R by buffering the local pH and regulating the interfacial microenvironment. 3.2 Coordination effect induced by cations Beyond the stabilizing influence induced by the interaction between the interface electric field and electric dipoles, the short-range electrostatic forces between intermediates and hydrated cations similarly exert a stabilizing effect [59]. Utilizing ab initio molecular dynamics simulations of Au-H2O-M+ systems, Monteiro et al. [45] proposed that partially solvated metal cations enhance the adsorption of CO2 on gold surfaces and promote the stability of *CO2 − through M-O (CO2) interaction, thus improving the selectivity and activity of eCO2R (Fig. 3(a) ). As the interaction between alkali cations and water molecules intensifies with the reduction in ion size, larger cations, which are more prone to dehydration, can stabilize reactants and intermediates through electrostatic interactions more effectively. Consequently, the propensity of cations to migrate from the bulk electrolyte to the OHP escalates with an increase in cation size, suggesting a size-dependent mechanism that influences the dynamics of eCO2R [60]. Furthermore, Marko et al. [61] employed constrained density functional theory molecular dynamics (cDFTMD) and slow growth DFT-MD (SG-DFT-MD) simulations to explore the pathways of outer spherical electron transfer (OS-ET) and inner spherical electron transfer (IS-ET) during the eCO2R process, delving into the initial step's cation effect. They found that in the absence of cations, the OS-ET pathway, leading to the formation of CO2 − (sol), is the sole route, albeit with a relatively high energy barrier (1.21 eV). Conversely, the presence of cations facilitates CO2 activation by favoring the IS-ET over OS-ET, substantially lowering the energy barriers to just 0.61 eV for K+ and 0.91 eV for Li+, thereby generating adsorbed CO2 δ− as a crucial intermediate for subsequent reduction steps. Cations modulate eCO2R via short-range Coulomb interactions, enhancing CO2 activation and electron transfer in the inner sphere by forming AM+-CO2 δ− coordination complexes (Fig. 3(b)). Although a unified theory elucidating the mechanism of cationic action in eCO2R remains elusive, it is anticipated that further advancements in DFT calculations will provide a deeper and more comprehensive understanding of the role of metal cations in the activation and stabilization of reactants and intermediates. This progress is expected to inspire novel approaches to applying acidic eCO2R in high-performance CO2 electrolysis, opening new avenues for efficient carbon capture and utilization technologies. 4 Design of eCO2R catalyst in acidic medium under the guidance of cationic effect In acidic electrolytes, the kinetic advantage of HER seriously hinders eCO2R. Additionally, conventional transition metal-based catalysts are prone to dissolution and corrosion in acidic conditions, leading to irreversible structural damage. Although precious metals have high acid resistance, they are not suitable to be used as catalysts for eCO2R [40]. Consequently, surmounting the hurdles related to the selectivity and durability of catalysis in acidic electrolytes represents a pressing challenge. This section highlights notable advancements in eCO2R within acidic environments in recent years, drawing upon these developments to examine the factors that influence eCO2R performance under the influence of cation effects. Furthermore, it compiles innovative design principles for catalysts and strategies aimed at enhancing performance, offering insights into overcoming the inherent challenges of eCO2R in acidic media. 4.1 Designing morphological structures The morphology of a catalyst critically influences the reaction microenvironment, impacting aspects such as hydrophobicity, adsorption capacity, electronegativity, localization, and both atomic and electronic structures. Through mechanisms like the tip effect, constraint effect, and the generation of local electric fields, it's possible to modulate the local concentration of OH− and H+ ions on the electrode surface, as well as the diffusion process of H+ [62–64]. This modulation can lead to an elevated local pH on the electrode surface, significantly affecting the performance of eCO2R. 4.1.1 Three-dimensional structures Three-dimensional (3D) structures, notably hollow and core-shell configurations featuring pores, can enforce spatial confinement effects that regulate ion diffusion. This is because diffusion coefficients within these structures are significantly lower than those outside, enhancing the selectivity and efficiency of eCO2R [65–67]. For example, Kang et al. [68] developed spherical hollow n-doped carbon nanocages encapsulating Ni nanoparticles. This configuration achieved an FE for CO of up to 84.3% in 0.25 mol L‒1 Na2SO4 + H2SO4 solution at pH = 2.5. This structure was found to impede proton diffusion within the Stern layer, thereby fostering a locally alkaline microenvironment conducive to CO2 reduction (Fig. 4(a) ). Similarly, Gong et al. [69] simulation studies demonstrated that the unique structure of Ag@C effectively regulates the diffusion of OH− and H+ ions, creating a high local pH on the catalyst surface which favors CO2 reduction in acidic conditions (Fig. 4(b)). Both examples illustrate how three-dimensional hollow structures can limit ion diffusion and enhance eCO2R by adjusting the reaction microenvironment. Moreover, these structures also influence the diffusion of cations close to the catalyst, confining cations within the cavity to produce a pronounced cation effect near the active sites, thereby significantly boosting eCO2R efficiency. The localized high concentration of cations not only restricts H+ migration but also enhances the kinetics of eCO2R. The local pH design strategy addresses the thermodynamic challenges of eCO2R in acidic media, enabling eCO2R to occur more readily than HER. However, in the heterogeneous aqueous system of eCO2R, water serves as the sole proton source. Over extended periods of high current operation, the consumption of H+ will inevitably cause the local pH to become alkaline. As electrolysis progresses, the effectiveness of this design strategy may gradually diminish, posing a new challenge to the stability of the electrolytic system. Through mathematical modeling, Derouane et al. [70]. demonstrated that the van der Waals forces exerted upon spherical molecules within a porous structure are more substantial than those in a planar arrangement. Therefore, CO2 molecules and intermediates can be easily enriched in porous catalysts, thus promoting the local increase of concentration. This concentration boost elevates the proportion of activated molecules per unit volume, thereby enhancing the likelihood of effective collisions among these molecules and accelerating the chemical reaction rate. In a distinctive work, Chen et al. [71] reported a hollow-fiber copper penetration electrode with a special structure, which can be stably electrolyzed for 100 h in H2SO4 and 3 mol L−1 KCl solution with pH = 0.7. This setup achieved an FE for C2+ of 73.4%, with a partial current density of −2.2 A cm−2. At a CO2 flow rate of 2 mL min−1, the SPCE for C2+ reached 51.8%. The electrode's self-supporting hollow fiber features a micron-scale cavity and a finger-like porous structure on its surface, enabling direct conversion of CO2 through its cavities. During electrolysis, CO2 is funneled directly into the fiber's cavity, where the constrained, three-dimensional environment forces CO2 to permeate through the porous walls and engage with active sites, thereby enhancing three-phase interface reactions. At the same time, the local proton consumption rate exceeds the proton transport rate from the bulk phase, creating a local alkaline environment that optimizes eCO2R kinetics and effectively generates C2+ products. This innovative electrolysis system ensures consistent and efficient CO2 delivery to the active sites, markedly improving mass transfer efficiency. Further insights from DFT calculations reveal that the adsorption of hydrated K+ ions enhances the hydrogenation of *CO to *CHO, as illustrated in Figs. 4(c) and (d), showcasing the intricate interplay between catalyst structure and electrolysis performance. Three-dimensional structures with high curvature, such as nano-urchins [72], nano-needles [73], and nano-dendrites [74], are characterized by abundant edges and angular sites. These features result in a reduced coordination number of atoms, narrowing the energy gap between the d-band center of the metal catalyst and the 2π* orbitals of CO [75,76]. This reduction significantly enhances the d-2π* back-donation from metal catalysts to CO, leading to stronger CO adsorption at these high-curvature sites, which facilitates C–C coupling processes [63]. For example, Cao et al. [77] prepared a dendritic copper catalyst (EC-Cu) by electrodeposition, achieving an FE for ethylene of 60%, with the total FE for C2+ products reaching up to 90% in a 2.5 mol L–1 KCl + H2SO4 solution. In situ time-resolved Raman spectra indicated an extended CO residence time on EC-Cu, with high surface concentrations of *OH and *CO enhancing the activity and selectivity towards C2+ products during eCO2R. Moreover, structures exhibiting high curvature can generate a local high electric field at the tips, enriching cations a phenomenon observed in eCO2R experiments in neutral and alkaline media [78]. For example, Liu et al. [79] demonstrated that the local high electric field generated around electro-deposited gold needles concentrates electrolyte cations, increasing local CO2 concentration near the catalyst surface and stabilizing *COOH intermediates to favor CO production. Finite element simulations revealed that, compared to other areas, the gold needle tips can accumulate electrons, thereby elevating the surface-adsorbed K+ concentration by 20-fold (Fig. 4(e)). Recently, Gao et al. [80] further found that the adsorption K+ concentration and the static electric field intensity increase as the curvature radius of the nanoneedle tip decreases (Fig. 4(f)). This tip effect-induced strategy of local high electric field enrichment offers a valuable approach that could be adapted to acidic media to achieve efficient eCO2R, presenting a promising direction for future research in enhancing electrocatalytic CO2 reduction. In a latest study, Zhai et al. [81] extended the application of this method to acidic media. They synthesized a dendritic copper oxide catalyst, where the dendritic morphology enhanced the enrichment of K+ ions (Fig. 4(g)). Moreover, the release of hydroxide ions is hindered, leading to OH‒ accumulating on the main branches in CuO x dendrites, which increases local pH. In 0.5 mol L−1 K2SO4 with a pH of 1.6, the FE of C2+ is 77% with a corresponding current density is −0.7A cm−2 (Fig. 4(h)). In situ Raman spectroscopy (Fig. 4(i)) further revealed changes in the local microenvironment. With the increase of applied voltage, the peak value of CO3 2− significantly increased, indicating an improvement in the local pH. 4.1.2 Two-dimensional structures Two-dimensional (2D) nanosheets, characterized by their highly exposed catalytic sites, provide optimal surfaces for cation interaction, enhancing the utilization of active sites and intermediates due to a multitude of active sites on the substrate [82,83]. Huang et al. [84] prepared Bi nanosheet catalysts (BiNS) with an average thickness of about 3.1 nm by one-pot reduction of bismuth nitrate pentahydrate. In a 0.05 mol L−1 H2SO4 + 3 mol L−1 KCl solution (pH < 1), these nanosheets achieved an FE of 92.2% for formic acid and a commercially relevant current density of −0.237 A cm−2. The presence of K+ was found to alter the catalyst surface's local microenvironment, inhibiting the HER and activating CO2 molecules by reducing proton coverage and local interaction, thereby facilitating efficient CO2 conversion to HCOOH in strongly acidic conditions (Figs. 5(a) , (b)). Gao et al. [85] developed vertically oriented bismuth nanosheets on a gas diffusion layer, creating cavities between the nanosheets that act as electrolyte reservoirs. These cavities constrained the movement of K+ ions and the in situ production of hydroxide, limiting proton diffusion and establishing a local alkaline environment. The approach yielded a formic acid FE of 96.3% in a pH = 2 electrolyte, alongside a notable local current density of −0.471 A cm−2. Enhancing eCO2R activity in acidic media can also be achieved by incorporating porous structures into 2D nanosheets through methods such as etching and ion exchange, leveraging confinement effects for cation enrichment. In a further study, Huang et al. [86] prepared porous Cu nanowires (ER-CuNS) by hydrothermal and electrochemical reduction methods, achieving in a strongly acidic 0.05 mol L−1 H2SO4 + 3 mol L−1 KCl solution (pH ≤ 1) an FE, partial current density, and SPCE for multi-carbon products of 83.7 ± 1.4%, −0.56 ± 0.02 A cm−2 and 54.4%, respectively. A comparative synthesis of flat Cu nanowires (F-CuNS) highlighted the pore structure's role in K+ enrichment. By transferring the catalyst-loaded electrode from the electrolyte to pure water while maintaining voltage, then discontinuing the voltage to release K+ ions for inductively coupled plasma (ICP) analysis, it was demonstrated that ER-CuNS adsorbed K+ ions at a rate 4.5 times higher than F-CuNS (Fig. 5(c)). This pronounced cation adsorption diminishes proton coverage on the Helmholtz plane and stabilizes key intermediates, thereby thermodynamically favoring *CO formation and C–C coupling (Fig. 5(d)). 4.2 Catalyst surface modification During reactions, the adsorption of CO2 molecules and intermediates on the catalyst surface significantly influences product distribution [87,88]. For example, the strong adsorption of *CO is pivotal in enhancing the formation of multi-carbon products [89–92]. Therefore, designing the surface properties of the catalyst to modulate the adsorption behaviors of reactants and intermediates is a strategic approach to augment eCO2R efficiency [93]. 4.2.1 Wettability regulation CO2 reduction occurs at the liquid-solid interface [94]. In acidic media, the higher proton concentration accelerates the kinetics of HER, making HER thermodynamically superior to eCO2R. Therefore, it is crucial to reduce the proton concentration on the electrode surface and inhibit the rapid diffusion of protons to the electrode surface. This can be achieved by creating a hydrophobic surface between the electrode surface and the electrolyte. Increasing the hydrophobicity of the electrode surface can isolate the aqueous solution, reduce the proton concentration at the interface, and ease the rapid evolution of protons into hydrogen. It also enhances the transport and capture of CO2 [95]. Molecules with long carbon chains or hydrophobic polymers such as polyethylene(PS) [96], polytetrafluoroethylene(PTFE) [97,98], 1-octadecanol [99,100], fluorosilane [101], n-butylamine [102], and stearic acid [103], are frequently used to regulate the hydrophobicity of catalyst surfaces. Through polymerization, grafting, and coating techniques, these hydrophobic chemicals affixed to the catalyst surface adjust the surface free energy and the configuration of bonding sites, enabling the formation of a hydrophobic [104]. Li et al. [105] introduced hydrophobic PTFE nanoparticles into the gas diffusion electrode's catalytic layer to fine-tune the microenvironment at the nickel-nitrogen-doped carbon (Ni-N-C) catalyst's solid-liquid-gas interface. This modification reduced overpotential and achieved nearly 100% FE for CO in 1 mol L‒1 Cs2SO4 at pH = 2, showcasing enhanced stability. Fig. 6(a) shows that PTFE modification optimizes the local ratio of CO2/H2O in the catalytic layer and reduces the thickness of the diffusion layer, thereby accelerating CO2 mass transfer and improving the performance of CO2R in the acidic electrolyte. Recently, Lin et al. [106] explored local hydrophobicity effects on acidic eCO2R by electrodepositing copper onto a carbon paper hydrophobic microporous layer (MPL). This highly hydrophobic setting yielded an FE for C2+ products of approximately 74% (Fig. 6(b)), illustrating that increased hydrophobicity impedes the diffusion of hydrated hydrogen ions and water to the electrode, slowing HER kinetics. Through AIMD simulation, the limiting effect of the hydrophobic microenvironment on OH– ion diffusion is revealed. Stable *OH reduces the energy barrier of C–C coupling of *CO, thus promoting the formation of multi-carbon products. Unfortunately, at high current densities, the hydrophobicity of the electrode surface cannot be maintained for a long time. This is mainly because, during prolonged operation, the electrolyte inevitably penetrates the gas diffusion electrode, compromising its inherent hydrophobicity. Additionally, traditional planar structures are not conducive to the stable contact between CO2 and the electrolyte, hindering further improvement in catalytic activity [12,107,108]. To overcome this challenge, Peng et al. [97] created hierarchical architectures with hierarchical porosity by electrospinning and heat treatment with PTFE, incorporating additional surface hydrophobic layers (Fig. 6(c)). This hydrophobic structure with hierarchical porosity greatly enhances CO2 mass transfer efficiency and electrode stability, allowing for stable operation for 273 h at 0.4 A cm−2 with 0.1 mol L−1 KHCO3. It can even run stably for more than 30 h even in strong acid media (Fig. 6(d)). In addition, Sun et al. [109] constructed sharp nano copper needles by electrooxidizing porous copper foils and treated the catalyst with 1-octadecyl mercaptan to render the catalyst hydrophobic, effectively reducing the local H+ ion concentration (Fig. 6(e)). The smaller tilt angle and apex angle enable rapid thermodynamic diffusion of CO2 at the catalyst-electrolyte interface (Fig. 6(f)). This unique structure achieves an FE of 87% and a partial current of −1.6 A cm−2 under acidic conditions. Remarkably, even when CO2 is diluted to 25%, the partial current density for C2+ products attains −0.34 A cm−2 (Fig. 6(g)). Currently, most studies use hydrophobic modifiers to separate catalysts and electrolytes. However, during prolonged electrolysis, these hydrophobic modifiers may gradually fall off and dissolve. Constructing hierarchical structures with intrinsic hydrophobicity represents a new direction for achieving industrial-scale carbon dioxide electrolysis. 4.2.2 Modification with functional material The physical and chemical properties of the catalyst surface can be modified by functional materials, such as organic molecules or polymers, which can adjust the diffusion behavior and adsorption intensity of the reactants and then adjust the product distribution. Nie et al. [110] designed a Cu electrode modified by an electrodeposited N-tolyl pyridinium (tolyl-pyr) film to enhance eCO2R activity by inhibiting proton diffusion. In the strong acid electrolyte with low K+ concentration, the FE for C2+ product reached 55%, in contrast to the predominant HER on unmodified electrodes (Fig. 7(a) ). In experiments conducted using an N2-saturated, unbuffered 0.1 mol L−1 KClO4/HClO4 solution (pH = 2.2), rotating disk electrode experiments were conducted with bare and modified copper electrodes. Compared with the bare Cu, the modified Cu shows a lower HER plateau current at each rotation rate, suggesting a diminished local concentration of H+ ions (Fig. 7(b)). The concentration of cations on the catalyst surface significantly affects the activity of eCO2R in acidic media. The higher distribution of cations on the catalyst surface can enhance the electric field to stabilize the eCO2R intermediates. Therefore, enhancing the adsorption of cations or weakening the diffusion of cations is a general strategy to improve the electrolytic activity of acidic CO2. Sargent et al. [20] used cationic perfluoro sulfonic acid (PFSA) ions to create cationic reinforcement layers on Cu surfaces. These layers can exchange protons with K+ in the electrolyte, maintaining high K+ concentrations on the catalyst surface and reducing OH− diffusion, thereby increasing surface pH. Under strongly acidic conditions and low CO2 flow rates, such modifications significantly improved the selective production of C2+ products (Figs. 7(c), (d)). Guo et al. [111] indicated that the 1-aza-18-crown-6-ether group fixed on iron porphyrins can bind to alkali metal cations in solution and enhance eCO2R activity. Cheng et al. [112] further exploited this property by combining 18-crown-6 with copper nanoparticles to investigate the performance of eCO2R in an acidic electrolyte. Confining K+ to the Cu electrode by 18-crown-6 can enhance the interfacial electric field strength and hydrolytic dissociation activity, promote the adsorption and protonation of *CO, and significantly improve the selectivity of methane compared to the unmodified catalyst (Figs. 7(e), (f)). Dong et al. [113] enhanced a silver-based GDE with a hydrophobic cationic-ionomer layer composed of quaternary ammonia poly and PTFE. This modification plays a pivotal role in modulating the surface electric field and insulating the catalyst's cathode electric field, thereby significantly reducing the undesired transmembrane diffusion of H+ and K+ ions. As a result, the FE for CO production soared to an impressive 95.6% at a current density of −0.1 A cm−2. Zhong et al. [40] tackled another critical issue affecting catalytic stability: corrosion by acidic mediums. They introduced a non-conductive, nanoporous SiC-Nafion™ layer onto the catalyst surface, acting as an ion-transfer regulatory layer to facilitate consistent eCO2R in acidic environments. This innovative layer rendered the catalyst surface's pH nearly neutral, owing to the structure's ability to restrict ion transfer near the surface and to concentrate K+ and OH‒ ions internally (Fig. 7(g)). In the demanding context of prolonged eCO2R in strong acids, this engineered electrolyte/catalyst interface creates a fundamentally stable environment, effectively protecting the catalyst from corrosive damage under cathodic potentials. The SnBi/PTFE-coated electrode exhibited remarkable durability, maintaining stable operation at pH = 1 for 125 h (Fig. 7(h)). 4.2.3 Enhancing surface coverage of intermediate A key factor contributing to the low selectivity of eCO2R products is the difference in adsorption strength that catalysts exhibit towards the complex array of intermediates. During CO2 reduction, the nature of the catalyst dictates the formation of different intermediates, which, in turn, follow varied catalytic pathways to yield distinct products [114]. Hence, tailoring the adsorption strength for crucial intermediates to augment their surface coverage on the catalyst can strategically promote the transformation of CO2 into desired products. Additionally, increasing the coverage of intermediates on the catalyst surface serves to diminish the surface occupancy by *H in acidic conditions, thereby slowing down the HER rate [115]. Zhong et al. [116] adjusted the adsorption energy of *OCHO, a key intermediate of eCO2R-to-formic acid, and prepared Cu-Sn alloys by combining Cu with Sn, a P-block metal known for its strong affinity towards oxygen and limited adsorption capacity for *H (Fig. 8(a) ). The Cu6Sn5 catalyst achieved a high FE of 91% for formic acid production at a current density of −1.2 A cm−2 within a strongly acidic electrolyte at pH = 1 (3 mol L−1 KCl + 0.05 mol L−1 H2SO4). In situ electrochemical attenuated total reflection Fourier-transform infrared (ATR-FTIR) spectroscopy analysis revealed a notable enhancement in *OCHO coverage on Cu6Sn5 catalyst—approximately 2.8 times greater than that on control catalysts made solely of tin under the same electrochemical conditions (Figs. 8(b), (c)). The eCO2R-to-C2+ products represent a promising avenue for transforming industrial production and achieving a green carbon cycle balance. At present, copper-based catalysts are widely used for deep reduction of CO2 to obtain multi-carbon products. However, eCO2R-to-C2+ products conversion still has a series of key technical bottlenecks, including slow reaction kinetics, complex coupling mechanisms, and insufficient intermediate coverage [9,117,118]. The synthesis of multi-carbon products hinges on the formation of CO and its subsequent coupling. Initially, CO2 is adsorbed onto the catalyst's surface and converted into CO, which, if stably adsorbed on a Cu-based catalyst, undergoes further deep reduction to multi-carbon products [119]. This concept introduces the notion of tandem catalysis, simplifying C2+ products formation into two discrete steps: CO generation/fixation and C–C coupling. Integrating strong CO adsorption catalysts (such as Pd) or catalysts that readily generate CO (like Au, Ag, Zn, and phthalocyanine) with Cu can produce a high in situ CO concentration on the surface, markedly enhancing C–C coupling kinetics [120–122]. For example, Sargent et al. [32] previously developed a bimetallic Pd-Cu catalyst, noting that CO2 adsorption on Pd-Cu was superior to Cu alone, 0.34 eV on Pd-Cu versus 0.68 eV on Cu, which led to less efficient CO* desorption and a greater likelihood of CO* protonation. CO*’s high affinity diminishes H* active site competition and weakens H binding energy, reducing HER activity and rendering Pd-Cu highly selective towards C2+ products. In a 0.5 mol L–1 K2SO4 solution (pH adjusted to 2.0 with sulfuric acid), a peak C2+ FE of 89% was achieved (Figs. 8(d)–(f)). Building on this, Sargent et al. [123] designed a tandem electrode system by integrating cobalt phthalocyanine (CoPc) with high CO selectivity and ionomer-modified copper nanoparticles (Cu NPs) with C–C coupling capability onto a sputtered Cu gas diffusion electrode in an acidic medium. CO2 gas traverses the gas diffusion layer and ion-modified Cu NP layer, reaching the CoPc@HC catalyst layer for CO conversion. The generated CO then diffuses back to the Cu NP layer for C–C coupling, significantly enhancing CO availability. This tandem structure achieved an 80% FE for C2+ products and a current density of −0.8 A cm−2 in a buffer acid electrolyte containing 0.5 mol L–1 H3PO4, 0.5 mol L–1 KH2PO4, and 2.5 mol L–1 KCl (Figs. 8(g)–(i)). In situ Raman spectroscopy confirmed CO's strong binding at Cu sites, while DFT calculations suggested that high CO surface coverage not only suppresses HER but also lowers the energy barrier for C–C coupling. 5 eCO2R in alkali metal cation-free acidic electrolytes A key benefit of conducting CO2 reduction in an acidic medium is the theoretical avoidance of carbonate formation, thereby enhancing CO2 utilization efficiency. Yet, during actual reactions, the concurrent consumption of H+ by both the HER and eCO2R near the cathode tends to increase local pH levels. This rise in pH may prompt the conversion of CO2 into (bi)carbonate ions. Additionally, the high concentration of cations in the solution tends to migrate and accumulate at the cathode due to electrostatic forces, further converting into salts. Although the electrolyte partially neutralizes these salts, complete prevention of salt precipitation within the GDE is challenging, affecting electrode durability. Furthermore, the migration of cations through the CEM to the anode can increase the cathode electrolyte's pH, further facilitating the conversion of CO2 to carbonates, which undermines the stable execution of acidic eCO2R [43]. Thus, managing the concentration of alkali ions while maintaining eCO2R efficiency presents a significant challenge [57,58,124]. CO2 reduction in acidic solutions without base cations can achieve sustainable CO2 electrolysis and maximize the solution to the carbonate issues. However, how to activate CO2 molecules without relying on cations is the primary problem facing CO2 electrolysis in pure acid media. Cations proximal to the cathode are instrumental in activating CO2 by generating an electric field or directly coordinating with CO2 molecules. Hence, replicating the effect of these cations without resorting to soluble alkali cations accumulating at the cathode presents a promising avenue for facilitating eCO2R in acidic environments devoid of metal cations. One innovative strategy involves anchoring a high density of cations onto the cathode surface. Sargent et al. [43] successfully immobilized benzimidazole cationic groups (CG) on a copper surface, achieving an 80% FE for C2+ products and over 90% SPCE in a 0.2 mol L‒1 H2SO4 solution (Figs. 9(a) , (b)). Simulation studies revealed that these surface-bound cationic groups generate an interfacial electric field comparable in magnitude to that of K+ ions in the electrolyte. This induced electric field acts as a local acidity buffer, enabling CO2 activation and C–C coupling even in strong acids (Fig. 9(c)). This approach underscores the potential for circumventing the reliance on metal cations in electrolytes, providing new ideas for efficient eCO2R under acidic conditions. Poly(diallyl dimethyl ammonium chloride) (PDDA) boasts a high cation density, making it an exemplary substitute for alkali cations due to its ability to form a stable ion layer on the catalyst surface. Nonetheless, PDDA's high solubility poses challenges to its stability in aqueous solutions. To address this, Gu et al. [124] devised a cross-linking technique to bolster PDDA's stability. Their cross-linked PDDA-modified Ag catalyst demonstrated consistent performance in a 0.1 mol L–1 H2SO4 solution over 36 h, maintaining an FE for CO above 80% (Fig. 9(d)). The electrolyte's absence of cations ensured stable pH levels at both the cathode and anode during reactions. Investigations utilizing an Ag micro-disk electrode (MDE) covered by various polymers and simulations based on the generalized modified Poisson-Nernst-Planck (GMPNP) model revealed that the polymer layer's cationic sites mimic natural cationic effects. These effects curb H+ migration, decrease HER efficiency, and bolster electric field-stabilized intermediates within the Stern layer, thereby expediting eCO2R (Figs. 9(e), (f)). Li et al. [125] achieved PDDA fixation through electrostatic assembly, layering positively charged PDDA onto negatively charged graphene oxide (Fig. 9(g)). Utilizing a PDDA-GO modified Ag catalyst in a 0.01 mol L–1 H2SO4 electrolyte yielded an optimal FE for CO of 85%. The PDDA-GO layer not only offers a cationic effect but also functions as a porous medium, enhancing local pH and CO2 accessibility (Figs. 9(h), (i)). This cationic modification approach enables eCO2R under acidic conditions devoid of metal cations, innovating a novel pathway for acidic medium eCO2R. The future exploration of new cationic polyelectrolytes and their immobilization techniques for inducing more potent cationic effects could significantly advance the sustainability and efficiency of CO2 reduction technologies. In addition, molecular catalysts with well-defined active sites and precisely customizable structures offer additional possibilities for further enhancing eCO2R activity in pure acid media. Designing functional groups capable of activating CO2 and stabilizing CO2 intermediates on molecular catalysts is a promising strategy to enhance the activity of eCO2R in metal-free, cationic acid electrolytes [58]. For example, guanidyl group [126], N,N-di(2-picolyl)ethylenediamine [127], N,N,N-trimethylbenzylamine groups [128], these functional groups can stabilize CO2 reduction intermediates through electrostatic interactions and further interact with water molecules to promote proton transfer. Molecules featuring functional groups like amino, pyridine, amine, and imidazole can directly interact with CO2 molecules [63]. These functionalities can expand the capabilities of eCO2R technology. 6 Summary and outlook The eCO2R under ambient conditions plays a pivotal role in mitigating carbon emissions and advancing toward carbon neutrality. While advancements have been made with alkaline and neutral electrolytes, the formation of (bi)carbonates has been a limiting factor in these environments. Acidic media offer a promising alternative by circumventing the (bi)carbonates formation issue, though they introduce challenges related to the HER, which competes with eCO2R, diminishing the efficiency of CO2 conversion in acidic settings. This review has provided an in-depth look at the latest developments aimed at enhancing the selectivity of CO2 electrolysis in acidic media. It has highlighted key advancements in improving product selectivity and electrocatalytic activity, emphasizing the importance of catalyst design and the significant role of cations in influencing the process. Rapid H+ reduction in acidic media is the main obstacle to the improvement of the electrolytic activity of acidic CO2. The activity of acidic CO2 electrolysis is directly related to the alkali metal cations in the solution. The alkali metal cations gathered near the cathode can inhibit the migration of H+, enhance the electric field of the Stern layer to activate CO2 and stabilize the intermediates. Therefore, based on the cationic effect, further design of the local microenvironment of the catalyst and the coverage of the intermediate is the basic principle of improving the electrolytic activity of acidic CO2. On this basis, as illustrated in Fig. 10 we summarized four specific approaches to provide ideas and guidance for readers to further develop new catalysts under acidic solutions. The first approach is to design the shape of the catalyst. The nanostructure with pores can act as a barrier to inhibit the diffusion of H+ in the bulk phase to the cathode and the migration of cations near the cathode to the bulk phase. In addition, the pore structure can further enrich the reaction intermediates and increase the eCO2R rate. The hierarchical architectures with high curvature structures can also induce the interfacial electric field and promote cation adsorption. The second approach is to construct a hydrophobic surface to reduce the H+ concentration on the catalyst surface. The third approach is to modify the catalyst with functional organic materials, especially organic materials that can trap cations and intermediates on the catalyst surface, which are essential to improve selectivity. In addition, sustainable CO2 electrolysis can be achieved by simulating cationic effects with organic materials, thereby replacing cations in electrolytes. The fourth approach is to design the adsorption strength of the intermediates, construct multiple active sites to weaken the binding strength of *H, and enhance the binding strength of CO2R intermediates, which can make eCO2R occur thermodynamically before HER. Although great progress has been made in eCO2R in acidic media, there are still some major challenges that need to be overcome. As shown in Fig. 11 , the following aspects should be focused on in the future development: 6.1 Developing efficient and stable catalytic systems For eCO2R's comprehensive advancement, a holistic technological approach is essential, encompassing catalyst design, ion exchange membrane, and reactor configuration. The pronounced activity of HER in acidic conditions detrimentally affects eCO2R, particularly hindering the Faradaic efficiency of products. While high cation concentrations can mitigate this issue and enhance eCO2R efficiency, enhancing the selectivity for specific products remains a challenge. Notably, producing C2+ products, which are highly valuable for their energy density and market demand, is complicated by the complexities of proton-coupled electron transfer (PCET) mechanisms and suboptimal eCO2R kinetics in acidic environments. This underscores the necessity for catalysts designed to precisely modulate their electronic structure and reaction microenvironment, thereby activating CO2 efficiently and catalyzing the formation of deeper reduction products. In particular, developing catalysts with high intrinsic activity to reduce the dependence on cations can avoid the problem of salt formation under prolonged operation with high currents. Developing a new GDE and using ionic liquid or organic liquid instead of water as proton source to avoid OH− formation will help completely solve the carbonate problem. Advancing anti-corrosion strategies for eCO2R stability in acidic media is urgent. Surface protection techniques and electrochemical protection methods serve as valuable references. Ideally, designing porous, hydrophobic polymer coatings or molecular catalysts could eliminate reliance on metal materials, though the impact of such coatings on active sites, the reaction environment, and catalyst activity warrants further investigation. Additionally, exploring traditional sacrificial anode strategies that employ highly reductive metals to create galvanic cells could offer solutions, though the potential for unintended HER necessitates careful examination. Enhancing ion exchange membrane technology, particularly through innovative and efficient BPM, holds significant promise for reducing anode material costs in acidic environments. Traditional membranes, limited to single-ion transport, fail to meet the complex demands of actual eCO2R systems, often leading to unexpected energy losses and reactant depletion. Achieving selective ion transport could markedly accelerate eCO2R development. Recent endeavors, like Lau et al.‘s integration of anion and cation exchange membranes to form an APEM system, offer inspiring advancements in ion exchange technology, suggesting a path forward for more efficient and stable eCO2R processes [129]. 6.2 Deepening reaction mechanism understanding Understanding the eCO2R mechanism is crucial due to its complexity and the diversity of potential products. Accurately identifying reaction pathways, particularly the PCET steps, is challenging but essential for optimizing catalysts, electrolytes, and equipment designs. Moreover, clarifying how cations influence eCO2R could enhance system efficiency and support the development of metal-free cationic eCO2R approaches, crucial for industrial scalability. Future research should prioritize advancing in situ characterization methods and computational models. Current techniques like in situ infrared and Raman spectroscopy, while useful, cannot fully capture the transient nature or low surface coverage of certain intermediates. Enhancing these technologies will provide deeper insights into the eCO2R process. Moreover, a single device cannot fully identify intermediates in the reaction process, and future exploration of the combination of multiple devices, such as in situ infrared and mass spectrometry, to better understand the reaction mechanism. Similarly, expanding beyond traditional DFT simulations will allow a better understanding of how microenvironmental changes affect eCO2R dynamics, particularly regarding cationic effects. 6.3 Expanding eCO2R technology development The focus in eCO2R research has largely been on optimizing cathode catalysts, but broader development is necessary. Key areas for expansion include: (1) Advanced CO2 Fixation: Reducing transportation and storage costs through in situ CO2 utilization is essential. Selectively enriching and converting CO2 directly at emission sources can mitigate the main source of CO2 pollution from flue gas emissions. (2) System Energy Efficiency: Optimizing the anode reaction can enhance the overall energy utilization of eCO2R systems. Integrating energy-efficient anode reactions, such as organic molecular anode oxidation like ethylene glycol and furfural, or constructing metal-CO2 batteries, which can be lithium, sodium, zinc, aluminum, magnesium, or potassium, could substantially improvements [130–132]. (3) Liquid Acid Product Separation: The separation of liquid acid products like formic acid in acidic media needs attention to overcome salt formation issues at higher pH levels. Improving selectivity and separation strategies is key to industrialization. Overall, the journey of eCO2R from foundational research to industrial application is fraught with significant challenges. Nonetheless, we are optimistic that ongoing and focused research will soon position large-scale electrocatalytic CO2 conversion as a key strategy for the sustainable management of the global carbon cycle. Min Kuang is currently a professor in the College of Materials Science and Engineering in Donghua University (China). She finished her PhD from Laboratory of Advanced Materials at Fudan University. After that, she joined the School of Materials Science and Engineering at Nanyang Technological University as a postdoctoral research associate. Her research interest is concentrating on developing advanced electrochemical C1-to-fuel conversion systems and the exploration of efficient electrocatalysts. Jianping Yang is appointed as a Professor and Associate Dean in the College of Materials Science and Engineering at Donghua University (China). He received his PhD in Inorganic Chemistry from Fudan University in 2013, and then worked as a postdoctoral and visiting research fellow at Tongji University, University of Wollongong and Monash University. His research interests include interfacial design of functional materials for environmental electrocatalysis, sustainable energy systems. Professor Yang has been admitted as a Fellow of the Royal Society of Chemistry (FRSC), and identified in the Highly Cited Researchers in Cross Field (2023) by Web of Science-Clarivate Analytics.

coredata.dc:description: The electrochemical reduction of CO2 (eCO2R) under ambient conditions is crucial for reducing carbon emissions and achieving carbon neutrality. Despite progress with alkaline and neutral electrolytes, their efficiency is limited by (bi)carbonates formation. Acidic media have emerged as a solution, addressing the (bi)carbonates challenge but introducing the issue of the hydrogen evolution reaction (HER), which reduces CO2 conversion efficiency in acidic environments. This review focuses on enhancing the selectivity of acidic CO2 electrolysis. It commences with an overview of the latest advancements in acidic CO2 electrolysis, focusing on product selectivity and electrocatalytic activity enhancements. It then delves into the critical factors shaping selectivity in acidic CO2 electrolysis, with a special emphasis on the influence of cations and catalyst design. Finally, the research challenges and personal perspectives of acidic CO2 electrolysis are suggested.
